p: Severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome (SFTS) caused by the SFTS virus (SFTSV) is an emerging infectious disease that was first identified in the rural areas of China in 2011 [ 1]. The patients are all from the hilly areas of central and northeastern China, and are mostly farmers working in the endemic areas. Most of the cases occur between April and October and Haemaphysalis longicornis is considered the most likely transmission vector [ 2– 4]. There were also reports of clustered cases and outbreaks of nosocomial infections [ 5, 6], indicating that except for the tick bite, there is a potential risk of human-to-human transmission [ 7– 9]. The major clinical manifestations of SFTS are fever, fatigue, thrombocytopenia and leucopenia, usually accompanied with myocardium impairment and elevated liver enzymes. Severe cases often die from multi-organ failure and the mortality rate of SFTS is 11.2%-30% [ 1, 10– 12].
